block.p: THERE isn't any construction going on at the New York Hall of Science, but you might be fooled into thinking so, given the bulky tool cart and orange flags roping off the Great Hall lobby. It's the Con Edison Millennium Manhole Cover Exhibition, through Sept. 3.

In 1884 the city required all electrical wires and cables to be placed underground. As a result, gas and electric companies produced their own manhole cover designs, and many original covers are still in place. The Millennium Manhole exhibition includes a rubbing station where you can create your own cover designs, view the work of eight artists who competed in a millennium manhole cover competition and see the winning design, ''Global Energy'' by Karim Rashid.

Charlie Silva, from the museum's public programs department, is shown here leading a tool cart demonstration in which you can try on hard hats and coveralls, try to lift manhole covers and find out what is inside the tool cart, on weekends at 12:30 p.m. and 3:30 p.m.

Con Edison's Millennium Manhole Exhibition; in August, Monday 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m., Tuesday through Sunday, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sept. 1 through 3 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park; free with museum admission: adults, $7.50; ages 4 to 17 and over 62, $5; (718) 699-0005.
